quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: People tend to get into a public speaking voice.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Calls out a common but counterproductive habit—switching into an unnatural persona when speaking publicly.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's so much more freeing, powerful, connecting, and effective to speak conversation.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to aim for conversational delivery rather than a “professional” performance voice.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In 2017, Tristan became the fastest competitor to reach the finals of the world championship of public speaking.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Establishes credibility with a specific, concrete achievement tied to elite public speaking performance.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I'd like to spend time on this topic on this podcast because becoming a better speaker is such an accelerant of your professional life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames public speaking skill as a high-leverage career multiplier, motivating focused practice.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So I took an abridged version of this speaking course that you teach called Ultraspeaking, and it immediately made me feel more comfortable public speaking, which I've never felt doing any other course.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific testimonial suggesting this approach differs meaningfully from conventional public speaking training.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core growth methodology and a way to evaluate new feature performance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous, deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Emphasizes the dual goal of moving faster while maintaining analytical rigor in experimentation programs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most was our experimentation platform, where I could set up experiments easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete example of empowering practitioners with self-serve tooling to run end-to-end experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The AI support agent can deflect upwards of 80% of support questions, providing actually useful answers, and it can magically co-browse with your users to show them around your interface.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides a specific performance claim and a practical tactic (co-browsing) for improving user support and onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They do pop-ups too, but their nudges are based on in-product behaviors like confusion or intent classification, which makes them much less annoying and much more impactful.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Offers a behavior-triggered nudge model as a less intrusive, higher-impact alternative to generic pop-ups.

quotes.topic_title: Speaking as a meta-skill and “debugging” yourself
quotes.text: And the reason it's so transformative is because speaking is not a specialized skill, it's a meta skill. That means that the better you get at speaking, the better your life gets.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Reframes public speaking as a meta-skill with compounding benefits across life, not a narrow performance skill.

quotes.topic_title: Speaking as a meta-skill and “debugging” yourself
quotes.text: So naturally, everything else in your life is going to start to improve as a result of you focusing on your fitness. And for speaking, it's the same thing.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Uses the fitness analogy to make the meta-skill concept concrete and actionable: improve the core, and downstream domains improve too.

quotes.topic_title: Speaking as a meta-skill and “debugging” yourself
quotes.text: So you don't need to teach a baby how to speak, it will learn by itself with no formal education. So what that means is, we all have this incredible hardware.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Counters the belief that speaking ability is rare or learned only through training by pointing to innate human “hardware.”

quotes.topic_title: Speaking as a meta-skill and “debugging” yourself
quotes.text: The thing is, over the course of our life, because of all these little situations that happen, we start getting bugs in the software and we're not really upgrading our software.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Introduces the “buggy software” model: anxiety and avoidance are fixable learned patterns, not permanent traits.

quotes.topic_title: Speaking as a meta-skill and “debugging” yourself
quotes.text: So all we need to do is some debugging and some upgrading of the software and suddenly your entire life can change. So that's really one I want to impart on anybody listening. You have it in, you already have what it takes.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Turns the framework into a practical methodology—debug and upgrade habits—while reinforcing self-efficacy.

quotes.topic_title: Enjoyment as a barometer for speaking well
quotes.text: I see enjoyment as a barometer, if I'm doing things right, I'm probably enjoying myself.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A simple mental model: use your level of enjoyment as real-time feedback for whether your speaking approach is working.

quotes.topic_title: Enjoyment as a barometer for speaking well
quotes.text: So as soon as things start not feeling enjoyable, it's a sign, hey, I'm probably doing this wrong, guy.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A counterintuitive diagnostic: discomfort isn’t something to push through blindly—it can indicate a flawed method.

quotes.topic_title: Enjoyment as a barometer for speaking well
quotes.text: So using speaking as a barometer of, hey, if this is not feeling good, I'm probably overthinking. I probably need to relax and try to just feel a little bit more like myself.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Actionable self-correction: when speaking feels bad, treat it as a cue to reduce control/overthinking and return to a natural mode.

quotes.topic_title: Enjoyment as a barometer for speaking well
quotes.text: Well, your practice has to be enjoyable as well because otherwise two weeks in, you're going to quit just like a shitty fitness journey or diet.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A practical sustainability rule: design practice to be enjoyable so you actually stick with it long enough to improve.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state and fixing root causes, not symptoms
quotes.text: The day I understood that speaking was a subconscious flow-oriented process and not a conscious process, completely changed the way I approached it.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Reframes public speaking improvement away from conscious tactics toward cultivating a flow-based, subconscious process.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state and fixing root causes, not symptoms
quotes.text: And the goal is to get into a flow state and stay in that flow state all the way through the finish line.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Defines a clear performance objective practitioners can train for: entering and maintaining flow throughout a talk.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state and fixing root causes, not symptoms
quotes.text: And one of the ways that changed how I practiced was, instead of focusing on the symptoms of speaking, I started to try and figure out, well, what are the root causes that create these symptoms, and can I address those?
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Introduces a root-cause methodology for improving speaking by targeting underlying drivers rather than surface-level issues.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state and fixing root causes, not symptoms
quotes.text: Solve that, and not only do the filler words take care of themselves, but the racing takes care of itself and you suddenly have more mind space.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Gives a practical cause-and-effect claim: addressing comfort with slowing down reduces multiple symptoms at once.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state and fixing root causes, not symptoms
quotes.text: So thinking through this and understanding that the goal here is upgrading the software and it's really layering, taking all the bad habits away and putting in new habits that I can just stay in this flow state without getting pulled out, that really changes the game.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model (“upgrading the software”) for habit replacement aimed at protecting flow under pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Three tactical tweaks: think up, end strong, stay in character
quotes.text: If instead you switch that up and you start thinking up. I think up into the right, but you can think in any direction you want, but as long as you're looking up, you actually look thoughtful by default.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A simple, immediately usable physical cue that changes how pauses are perceived (thoughtful/confident vs. uncertain).

quotes.topic_title: Three tactical tweaks: think up, end strong, stay in character
quotes.text: I recommend writing, think up, on a post-it and putting it on your computer so that it's there for you.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A practical habit-installation tactic to make the “think up” behavior stick in real meetings/Zoom calls.

quotes.topic_title: Three tactical tweaks: think up, end strong, stay in character
quotes.text: They put freestyle rappers in an fMRI, and what they found out is freestyle rappers have to enter a deep flow state.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Uses a concrete research example to explain why speakers naturally fall out of flow near the end and start weakening their finish.

quotes.topic_title: Three tactical tweaks: think up, end strong, stay in character
quotes.text: So you get to the end, you're like, okay, I got to wrap up now. And so you'll say, "So to wrap up..." And your brain's going to fill in the gap.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Introduces “summary prompts” as a repeatable method to reliably close strong without tapering off.

quotes.topic_title: Three tactical tweaks: think up, end strong, stay in character
quotes.text: People cannot see what you feel, even though it feels that way when you feel really, really strongly, but people can't see it.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that internal insecurity is usually invisible—reducing the urge to hedge or “break character.”

quotes.topic_title: Why people “leak” and how to stop
quotes.text: It's because you're convinced that everybody can tell.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Pinpoints the core (often false) belief that drives people to “leak” by calling attention to perceived mistakes.

quotes.topic_title: Why people “leak” and how to stop
quotes.text: It's like, hey, everybody, you're driving a train, everybody's in the train, you're the driver as the speaker, everybody's going with you. So if there's a crash on the side of the road, you can keep going and they'll not be looking at the crash a second later and they'll be looking at the next landscape, or you can stop the train and tell everybody, "Hey, let's look at this crash here real quick. I'm so sorry about it."
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A memorable mental model showing why acknowledging small errors often amplifies them—and why continuing confidently is usually better.

quotes.topic_title: Why people “leak” and how to stop
quotes.text: And with the peak end rule, what we we're seeing, people remember the end of experiences more than they remember the beginning of experiences.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Introduces a behavioral principle to guide speakers: prioritize finishing strong instead of fixating on early stumbles.

quotes.topic_title: Why people “leak” and how to stop
quotes.text: The other piece is, because most people won't notice it in the first place, they'll be in their own minds. So when you share this, you're popping their bubble.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that audiences are often less aware than you think—until you point out the problem for them.

quotes.topic_title: Why people “leak” and how to stop
quotes.text: But this habit of saying, "No, I'm going to be confident, I'm leading, I'm going to keep us going in a certain direction," is extremely powerful and very self-reinforcing.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Actionable advice: adopt a default “keep going” leadership stance to prevent spiraling and build confidence over time.

quotes.topic_title: Why Ultraspeaking uses games for practice
quotes.text: But maybe the bad news is, you have to do it. You have to ask yourself, "Am I going to be serious about taking on speaking and making a difference here?" And if you are, then you're going to have to do the thing. You have to practice speaking.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A blunt, actionable reframing: improvement requires doing the scary core behavior (speaking), not consuming more advice.

quotes.topic_title: Why Ultraspeaking uses games for practice
quotes.text: But what all of the Ultraspeaking games have in common is that it's short, deliberate practice, short reps followed by feedback, followed by another rep.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A clear practice methodology practitioners can copy: tight repetition loops with immediate feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Why Ultraspeaking uses games for practice
quotes.text: And the longer they spent thinking, the worse their answer tended to be, and the more their confidence tended to go down as they were speaking.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that overthinking degrades both content and delivery, motivating faster starts.

quotes.topic_title: Why Ultraspeaking uses games for practice
quotes.text: The magic of games is short reps, immediate feedback, practice feedback, practice feedback.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A memorable summary of why games work: they operationalize rapid iteration and learning-by-doing.

quotes.topic_title: Why Ultraspeaking uses games for practice
quotes.text: And we would say, we would give him a speech title just to get a baseline. "Okay, what's the most incredible invention in the world?" And we'd watch this person go into their mind and start freaking out.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A concrete example of the common failure mode (freezing/spiraling) that the games are designed to interrupt.

quotes.topic_title: Live game: Conductor explained and demoed
quotes.text: The way this game works is that when I click "start training," I'm going to have a random title that's going to appear.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Sets up the Conductor exercise as a repeatable training method using random prompts to practice speaking under constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Live game: Conductor explained and demoed
quotes.text: But then, I might see a number from one to 10, and each one of these numbers represents an intensity or a state that I have to tap into.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Introduces a simple intensity scale that forces deliberate control over vocal energy and emotional state while speaking.

quotes.topic_title: Live game: Conductor explained and demoed
quotes.text: And then, there might be a slide that says "breathe," which is just an indication to pause.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Adds an explicit pause cue to train comfort with silence and regulate nerves mid-speech.

quotes.topic_title: Live game: Conductor explained and demoed
quotes.text: And when I see that slide "breathe," if I just go silent, that's because I'm in front of the breathe slide and I'm not allowed to speak.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Makes pausing non-optional, turning silence into a practiced skill rather than an anxiety trigger.

quotes.topic_title: Live game: Conductor explained and demoed
quotes.text: And in that moment, my goal is just to relax myself and calm myself and then see what happens where I'm at when that slide moves on to the next one.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Gives a concrete objective during pauses—downshift physiology—so speakers can reset and continue with control.

quotes.topic_title: Lenny plays Conductor; coaching on mindset
quotes.text: It's funny, because what it looked like to me is that, well, you just didn't let yourself play the game. You wanted to... You were more focused on, "I want to make sure this works well, this looks good, or I don't make a fool of myself" than "Let me just play the game."
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A practical mindset shift: anxiety and stiffness come from prioritizing performance over play, so refocus on the activity itself.

quotes.topic_title: Lenny plays Conductor; coaching on mindset
quotes.text: So switch your mindset from that. Back in the Creator Cohort, you didn't really care, because if you failed, it didn't matter. So you just played the game. And this is the same idea. Just don't try. Just let yourself play the game.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Counterintuitive coaching: reducing effort toward “doing well” can improve results by restoring experimentation and play.

quotes.topic_title: Lenny plays Conductor; coaching on mindset
quotes.text: So the point of all of these games is to create turbulence.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A clear methodology: deliberately introduce stressors in practice so real situations feel manageable.

quotes.topic_title: Lenny plays Conductor; coaching on mindset
quotes.text: But if you think about a pilot, a flight simulator, you can think about these games as the flight simulator. You don't put a pilot in a flight simulator and waste those precious hours having them just cruise at 30,000 feet in clear skies. You're going to say, "Okay, you're going and now hey, you've lost your captain and you have to do something" or "Hey, your motor just broke" or "You're going into crazy turbulence."
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: effective training simulates worst-case conditions, not easy reps, to build resilience under pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Turbulence training and lessons from Conductor
quotes.text: So the point of all of these games is to create turbulence.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Frames practice games as intentionally stressful “simulators” that expose weaknesses and build real-world resilience.

quotes.topic_title: Turbulence training and lessons from Conductor
quotes.text: There's no way you can prepare for Conductor. You can do just a ton of reps and get to become the person who can just navigate the turbulence really, really gracefully.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: Emphasizes repetition over preparation for spontaneous speaking, training recovery under pressure rather than scripted perfection.

quotes.topic_title: Turbulence training and lessons from Conductor
quotes.text: Pros are just amateurs who've learned to recover gracefully from their mistakes.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A memorable redefinition of mastery that shifts focus from avoiding mistakes to recovering well.

quotes.topic_title: Turbulence training and lessons from Conductor
quotes.text: every energy level, like a one when you go low and a 10 or even a five, when you're at that energy level, you access different insights and memories and stories.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Introduces a practical mental model: changing energy levels can unlock different “folders” of thoughts and material.

quotes.topic_title: Turbulence training and lessons from Conductor
quotes.text: So it's energy leads, emotions follow, and words fill in the gap.
quotes.speaker: Tristan de Montebello
quotes.context: A simple, actionable sequence for improvisation: adjust energy to shape emotion, and let language emerge naturally.
